chunks.en: My home was burglarized during the Chinese New Year. Are there any camera recommendations?

My home is in the countryside. During the Chinese New Year, people were visiting, and no one was home, so my house was burglarized. Fortunately, I don't use cash much anymore, otherwise the losses would have been severe.

I plan to buy two cameras, one to install at home (with internet, rainproof). One outdoors (with electricity, but no internet, poor rain protection. I plan to use an old mobile phone to share a hotspot for the camera or buy one with its own data card). Are there any suitable camera recommendations? It's best to support NAS, otherwise, I'll be even angrier if the card is pulled out. Buying cloud storage seems quite expensive, thank you!

How are Hikvision and Xiaomi?
Hikvision is already a leading company in the monitoring industry, so there's definitely no problem.
My store also sells Hikvision, and the shipments are large.
EZVIZ C8C Outdoor Waterproof WiFi + RJ45
EZVIZ C6C Indoor Non-Waterproof WiFi + RJ45

chunks.en: Stability is pretty stable, but there are a few points: 1. The outdoor camera becomes blurry at night after a long time. It is said that you can adjust the ISO exposure parameters, but I haven't tried it.
2. EZVIZ's indoor camera uses resin lenses, which age over time, like a person getting cataracts. It is said that you can replace the lens separately, but I haven't tried it.
3. Network delay, when connecting back to home from another location to watch playback or live stream, it basically lags. Even when the camera rotates, it lags terribly.
You can match it with a few fake cameras, which are low cost

chunks.en: Hikvision supports Onvif and GB28181 protocols, and can be connected to Synology's camera suite and NVR (brand is not limited).
Xiaomi seems to only support the SMB protocol, but it can also be connected to Synology.
If you want to use it outdoors, don't buy the kind that's placed indoors. You can buy bullet cameras or PTZ cameras.
@v2maxwell TP-Link doesn't give 3 days.
I bought two Xiaomis for my home, and used a 256G memory card to store the data, which can retain more than 20 days of recording.
How far is your outdoors...can't WiFi cover it???
Also, I suggest buying cloud storage.
I use TP-Link at my home and my parents' home, and 7 days of cloud storage is only 150 for two years.
It's quite cheap.
Xiaomi, one APP solves everything, convenient and easy to use.
I use Xiaomi, and put in a 64g card. If I only store the images when the picture changes, I can store about 2 months of video.
For outdoor use, you can consider a 4G camera that uses data, using a WiFi hotspot is unreliable.

There is a special device that converts 4G to a network port for camera use, a few dollars each, the effect is unknown.

chunks.en: I have 4 cameras, I bought a video recorder for about 60, and each camera costs about 80 later. Then I bought 100m of network cable, two poe switches, about 50 each.
The hard drive is 1t from my old computer.
Except for the switch and network cable, everything else is second-hand.
I feel there's no need to put the data on the NAS.
I use Xiaomi, and the Mijia app is very convenient to use.
I use EZVIZ both indoors and outdoors, it's very stable and hasn't had any problems.
The outdoor one uses EZVIZ solar + 4G, comes with free data, and opening a cloud service costs 120 a year. The new model is HB8, I just bought a set and plan to use it in another house.
There are many Migu Home devices sold on Xianyu (a used goods platform), the prices are cheap, and they can also be used.

Using a host, it seems that Hikvision's system no longer has email alerts, which is very important. If the hard drive is taken away, you can still see the pictures if you have an email alert. Also, they use computer software to view it, and can instantly pop up alarm pictures on the computer, but they just won't let you save them. I don't know what they are thinking.

Using a card, a special reminder: someone here has said before that many brands will stop recording after the network is disconnected, that is to say, the thief cuts your network cable and doesn't even need to unplug the card. I'm not sure if this is true, anyway someone here posted about it before.
I have to say, the people who make surveillance systems these days are very thoughtful about making it convenient for thieves.
